intro: Perityle emoryi var. orcuttii, commonly known as the Emory's perityle, is a rare flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and nutrient-poor conditions. Its flowers are usually small and yellow, appearing in clusters, and it blooms during the spring and early summer. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
